animalOfTheDay.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.

calendar.name: stick insect
facts: Stick insects are among the longest insects, with some species reaching over 2 feet in length.
They can regenerate lost limbs when they molt.
Some species can reproduce without males through parthenogenesis.
Stick insects are masters of camouflage, resembling twigs or leaves.

calendar.name: stingray
facts: They use electroreceptors to detect the electrical signals of prey hidden in the sand.
Stingrays 'fly' through the water by flapping their pectoral fins like wings.
Their stingers are modified scales and can deliver venom, but they only use them in self-defense.
Stingrays are closely related to sharks and have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.
Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.
Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.

randomAnimals.name: caracal
facts: Caracals can leap up to 10 feet high to catch birds in flight.
Their distinctive ear tufts help funnel sound to improve their hearing.
Caracals were once trained by Indian royalty to hunt birds.
They can survive without drinking water, getting moisture from their prey.

randomAnimals.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs â€“ each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.

randomAnimals.name: sea lion
facts: Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.
Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
